anchor.surface_text: Excisable goods is defined by s. 2 d , and means goods specified in the First Schedule as being subject to a duty of excise and includes salt. anchor.surface_text: Excisable goods is defined by s. 2 d , and means goods specified in the First Schedule as being subject to a duty of excise and includes salt. holdings.reasoning_summary: s.2(d) defines excisable goods as those in First Schedule subject to duty plus salt; s.3(1) levies duty only on such excisable goods produced/manufactured in India

holdings.text: The effect of consolidation in Central Excises and Salt Act, 1944 was not to codify the law so as to repeal other acts not specifically mentioned; no negative provision contemplated

anchor.surface_text: Prior to the enactment of this consolidating Act, there were not less than 17 Acts dealing with different commodities, and in 1944, all those laws were repealed, and a consolidated Act was passed to cover all those Acts and to include certain new commodities. The effect of consolidation was not to codify the law in such a way as to repeal other acts,

holdings.reasoning_summary: 1944 Act explicitly repealed 17 prior specific Acts on listed commodities; no express or implied repeal of non-corresponding local laws on unscheduled goods; no negative words excluding levy on other commodities

anchor.surface_text: Excisable goods is defined by s. 2 d , and means goods specified in the First Schedule as being subject to a duty of excise and includes salt. These two provisions read together limit the, operation of the excise law to enumerated companymodities and salt, and the ambit of the law is thus companyfined.

The result, therefore, is quite clear that the Robkar, under which the royalty was imposed cannot be said to be a law corresponding to the Central Excises and Salt Act, 1944, and is, therefore, not within the repeal created by s. 13 2  of the Finance Act, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The provisions of s. 13 2  of the Finance, Act, 1950, clearly show that only a law corresponding to the Central Excises and Salt Act, 1944, was intended to be repealed.

The result, therefore, is quite clear that the Robkar, under which the royalty was imposed cannot be said to be a law corresponding to the Central Excises and Salt Act, 1944, and is, therefore, not within the repeal created by s. 13 2  of the Finance Act, 1950.
ts. M. Sikri, Advocate-General for the State of Punjab, N. Bindra and P.D. Menon, for the respondent. 1961. July 28. Judgment of the Court was deliver

anchor.surface_text: is whether the levy of royalty at Rs. 50 per one lakh bricks under a Robkar issued by the Ijlas-i-Khas  Council of Regency , Patiala State, on February 6, 1919, is valid.

The result, therefore, is quite clear that the Robkar, under which the royalty was imposed cannot be said to be a law corresponding to the Central Excises and Salt Act, 1944, and is, therefore, not within the repeal created by s. 13 2  of the Finance Act, 1950.
